column1: Information : October 17
Information : The Third Gore-Bush Presidential Debate
Jim Lehrer : Good evening from the Field House at Washington University in St. Louis.
Jim Lehrer : I'm Jim Lehrer of the NewsHour on PBS.
Jim Lehrer : And I welcome you to this third and final Campaign 2000 debate between the Democratic candidate for president
column2: Vice President Al Gore
column3: and the Republican candidate
column4: Governor George W. Bush of Texas.

column1: Jim Lehrer : Let's welcome the candidates now.
Jim Lehrer : [Applause]
Jim Lehrer : Before proceeding tonight we would like to observe a moment of silence in memory of Governor Mel Carnahan of Missouri
column2: who along with his son and his former chief of staff
column3: died in a private plane crash last night near St. Louis.

column1: Jim Lehrer : A reminder
column2: as we continue now
column3: that these debates are sponsored by the Commission on Presidential Debates.

column1: Jim Lehrer : The formats and the rules were worked out by the commission and the two campaigns.
Jim Lehrer : Tonight's questions will be asked by St. Louis area voters who were identified as being uncommitted by the Gallup organization.
Jim Lehrer : Earlier today each of them wrote a question on a small card like this.
Jim Lehrer : Those cards were collected and then given to me this afternoon.
Jim Lehrer : My job
column2: under the rules of the evening
column3: was to decide the order the questions will be asked and to call on the questioners accordingly.

column1: Jim Lehrer : I also have the option of asking follow-ups which -- in order to get to more of the panel's questions.
Jim Lehrer : For the record
column2: I plan to do sparingly and mostly for clarifications.

column1: Jim Lehrer : The audience participants are bound by the following rule.
Jim Lehrer : They shall not ask follow-up questions or otherwise participate in the extended discussion.
Jim Lehrer : And the questioner's microphone will be turned off after he or she completes asking the question.
Jim Lehrer : Those are the rules.
Jim Lehrer : As in Winston-Salem last week
column2: no single answer or response from a candidate can exceed two minutes.

column1: Jim Lehrer : There is an audience here in the hall and they have promised to remain absolutely quiet
column2: as did their predecessors this year in Boston
column3: Danville
column4: and Winston-Salem.

column1: Jim Lehrer : Before we begin
column2: a correction from last week's debate.

column1: Jim Lehrer : I was wrong when I said Vice President Gore's campaign commercials had called Governor Bush a bumbler.
Jim Lehrer : That specific charge was made in a press statement by Gore campaign spokesman Mark Fabiani
column2: not in a TV Guide.

column1: Al Gore : I'm glad you clarified that.
Jim Lehrer : Now
column2: let's go to the first question.

column1: Jim Lehrer : Of over the 130 questions we received from this panel
column2: we will begin with one of the 19 on health issues
column3: and it goes to you
column4: Mr. Vice President
column5: and it will be asked by James Hankins.

column1: Jim Lehrer : Mr. Hankins?
AUDIENCE MEMBER : How do you feel about HMOs and insurance companies making the critical decisions that affect people's lives instead of the medical professionals
column2: and why are the HMOs and insurance companies not held accountable for their decisions?

column1: Al Gore : Mr. Hankins
column2: I don't feel good about it
column3: and I think we ought to have a patient's bill of rights to take the medical decisions away from the HMOs and give them back to the doctors and nurses.

column1: Al Gore : I want to come back and tell you why
column2: but if you will forgive me
column3: I would like to say something right now at the beginning of this debate following on the moment of silence for Mel Carnahan and Randy Carnahan and Chris Sifford.

column1: Al Gore : Tipper and I were good friends with Mel and Randy
column2: and I know that all of us here want to extend our sympathy and condolences to Jean and the family and to the Sifford family.

column1: Al Gore : And I would just like to say that this debate in a way is a living tribute to Mel Carnahan because he loved the vigorous discussion of ideas in our democracy.
Al Gore : He was a fantastic governor of Missouri.
Al Gore : This state became one of the top five in the nation for health care coverage for children under his leadership.
Al Gore : One of the best in advancing all kinds of benefits for children to grow up healthy and strong.
Al Gore : And of course
column2: this debate also takes place at a time when the tragedy of the USS Cole is on our minds and hearts and insofar as the memorial service is tomorrow
column3: I would like to also extend sympathy to the families of those who have died and those who are still missing
column4: and the injured.

column1: Al Gore : Now
column2: Mr. Hankins
column3: I think that the situation that you describe has gotten completely out of hand.

column1: Al Gore : Doctors are giving prescriptions
column2: they're recommending treatments
column3: and then their recommendations are being overruled by HMOs and insurance companies.

column1: Al Gore : That is unacceptable.
Al Gore : I support a strong national patient's bill of rights.
Al Gore : It is actually a disagreement between us
column2: a national law that is pending on this
column3: the Dingle-Norwood bill
column4: a bipartisan bill
column5: is one that I support and that the governor does not.

column1: Jim Lehrer : Two minutes response
column2: Governor Bush.

column1: George W. Bush : I
column2: too
column3: want to extend my prayers and blessings
column4: God's blessings on the families whose lives were overturned yes -- tod -- last night.

column1: George W. Bush : It's a tragic moment.
George W. Bush : Actually
column2: Mr. Vice President
column3: it's not true.

column1: George W. Bush : I do support a national patient's bill of rights.
George W. Bush : As a matter of fact
column2: I brought Republicans and Democrats together to do just that in the State of Texas to get a patient's bill of rights through.

column1: George W. Bush : It requires a different kind of leadership style to do it
column2: though.

column1: George W. Bush : You see
column2: in order to get something done on behalf of the people
column3: you have to put partisanship aside
column4: and that's what we did in my state.

column1: George W. Bush : We have one of the most advanced patient's bill of rights.
George W. Bush : It says
column2: for example
column3: that a woman doesn't have to go through a gate keeper to go to her gynecologist.

column1: George W. Bush : It says that you can't gag a doctor
column2: doctor can advise you.

column1: George W. Bush : The HMO
column2: the insurance company
column3: can't gag that doctor from giving you full advice.

column1: George W. Bush : And this particular bill
column2: it allows patients to choose a doctor
column3: their own doctor if they want to.

column1: George W. Bush : But we did something else that was interesting.
George W. Bush : We're one of the first states that said you can sue an HMO for denying you proper coverage.
George W. Bush : Now there's what's called an Independent Review Organization that you have to go through first.
George W. Bush : It says if you˘âĴâ˘ve got a complaint with your insurance company
column2: you can take your complaint to an objective body.

column1: George W. Bush : If the objective body rules on your behalf
column2: the insurance company must follow those rules.

column1: George W. Bush : However
column2: if the insurance company doesn't follow the findings of the IRO
column3: then that becomes a cause of action in a court of law.

column1: George W. Bush : It's time for our nation to come together and do what's right for the people
column2: and I think this is right for the people.

column1: George W. Bush : You know
column2: I support a national patient's bill of rights
column3: Mr. Vice President
column4: and I want all people covered.

column1: George W. Bush : I don't want the law to supersede good law like we've got in Texas.
George W. Bush : I think --
Jim Lehrer : Governor
column2: time is up
column3: sir.

column1: Al Gore : Jim
column2: we have a direct disagreement on this.

column1: Jim Lehrer : Just a minute
column2: Mr. Vice President.

column1: Jim Lehrer : I want to -- the way the rules go here now
column2: two minutes
column3: two minutes
column4: and then I'll decide whether we go on.

column1: Jim Lehrer : Okay.
Jim Lehrer : So what I want to make sure is we understand here is before we go on to another question in the health area
column2: would you agree that you two agree on a national patient's bill of rights?

column1: Al Gore : Absolutely not.
Al Gore : I referred to the Dingle-Norwood bill.
Al Gore : It is the bipartisan bill that is now pending in the Congress.
Al Gore : The HMOs and the insurance companies support the other bill that's pending
column2: the one that the Republican majority has put forward.

column1: Al Gore : They like it because it doesn't accomplish what I think really needs to be accomplished to give the decisions back to the doctors and nurses and give you a right of appeal to somebody other than the HMO or insurance company
column2: let you go to the nearest emergency room without having to call an HMO before you call 911
column3: to let you see a specialist if you need to
column4: and it has strong bipartisan support.

column1: Al Gore : It is being blocked by the Republican leadership in the Congress.
Jim Lehrer : Sir.
Al Gore : And I specifically would like to know whether Governor Bush will support the Dingle-Norwood bill
column2: which is the main one pending.

column1: Jim Lehrer : Governor Bush
column2: you may answer that if you'd like.

column1: Jim Lehrer : But also I'd like to know how you see the differences between the two of you
column2: and we need to move on.

column1: George W. Bush : Well
column2: the difference is is that I can get it done.

column1: George W. Bush : That I can get something positive done on behalf of the people.
George W. Bush : That's what the question in this campaign is about.
George W. Bush : It's not only what's your philosophy and what's your position on issues
column2: but can you get things done?

column1: George W. Bush : And I believe I can.
Al Gore : What about the Dingle-Norwood bill?
Jim Lehrer : All right.
Jim Lehrer : We're going to go now to another -- all right.
Jim Lehrer : Yes.
George W. Bush : I'm not quite through.
George W. Bush : Let me finish.
George W. Bush : I talked about the principles and the issues that I think are important in a patient's bill of rights.
George W. Bush : It's kind of Washington
column2: D.C. focus.

column1: George W. Bush : Well
column2: it's in this committee or it's got this sponsor.

column1: George W. Bush : If I'm the president
column2: we're going to have emergency room care
column3: we're going have gag orders
column4: we're going to have direct access to OB/GYN.

column1: George W. Bush : People will be able to take their HMO insurance company to court.
George W. Bush : That's what I've done in Texas and that's the kind of leadership style I'll bring to Washington.
Jim Lehrer : All right.
Jim Lehrer : Another -- the next question also on health issue is from -- it will be asked by Marie Payne Kloepy
column2: and it goes to Governor Bush.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER : Are either of you concerned with -- are either of you concerned with finding some feasible way to lower the price of pharmaceutical drugs such as education on minimizing intake
column2: revamp of the FDA process or streamlining the drug companies' procedures instead of just finding more money to pay for them?

column1: George W. Bush : Well
column2: that's a great question.

column1: George W. Bush : I think one of the problems we have
column2: particularly for seniors
column3: is there is no prescription drug coverage in Medicare.

column1: George W. Bush : And therefore
column2: when they have to try to purchase drugs they do so on their own
column3: there's no kind of collective bargaining
column4: no power of purchasing among seniors.

column1: George W. Bush : So I think step one to make sure prescription drugs is more affordable for seniors
column2: and those are the folks who really rely upon prescription drugs a lot these days
column3: is to reform the Medicare system
column4: is to have prescription drugs as an integral part of Medicare once and for all.

column1: George W. Bush : The problem we have today is like the patient's bill of rights
column2: particularly with health care
column3: there's a lot of bickering in Washington
column4: D.C.

column1: George W. Bush : It's kind of like a political issue as opposed to a people issue.
George W. Bush : So what I want to do is I want to call upon Republicans and Democrats to forget all the arguing and finger pointing
column2: and come together and take care of our seniors' prescription drug program
column3: that says we'll pay for the poor seniors
column4: we'll help all seniors with prescription drugs.

column1: George W. Bush : In the meantime
column2: I think it's important to have what's called Immediate Helping Hand
column3: which is direct money to states so that seniors
column4: poor seniors
column5: don't have to choose between food and medicine.

column1: George W. Bush : That's part of an overall overhaul.
George W. Bush : The purchasing powers.
George W. Bush : And I'm against price controls.
George W. Bush : I think price controls would hurt our ability to continue important research and development.
George W. Bush : Drug therapies are replacing a lot of medicines as we used to know it.
George W. Bush : One of the most important things is to continue the research and development component.
George W. Bush : And so I'm against price controls.
George W. Bush : Expediting drugs through the FDA makes sense
column2: of course.

column1: George W. Bush : Allowing the new bill that was passed in the Congress made sense to allow for
column2: you know
column3: drugs that were sold overseas to come back and other countries to come back into the United States.

column1: George W. Bush : That makes sense.
George W. Bush : But the best thing to do is to reform Medicare.
Jim Lehrer : Vice President Gore
column2: two minutes.

column1: Al Gore : All right
column2: here we go again.

column1: Al Gore : Now look
column2: if you want someone who will spend a lot of words describing a whole convoluted process and then end up supporting legislation that is supported by the big drug companies
column3: this is your man.

column1: Al Gore : If you want someone who will fight for you and who will fight for the middle-class families and working men and women
column2: who are sick and tired of having their parents and grandparents pay higher prices for prescription drugs than anybody else
column3: then I want to fight for you.

column1: Al Gore : And you asked a great question because it's not only seniors.
Al Gore : Listen
column2: for 24 years I have never been afraid to take on the big drug companies.

column1: Al Gore : They do some great things.
Al Gore : They discover great new cures and that's great.
Al Gore : We want them to continue that.
Al Gore : But they are now spending more money on advertising and promotion.
Al Gore : You see all these ads?
Al Gore : Than they are on research and development.
Al Gore : And they are trying artificially extend the monopoly patent protection so they can keep charging these very high prices.
Al Gore : I want to streamline the approval of the competing generic drugs and the new kinds of treatments that can compete with them so we bring the price down for everybody.
Al Gore : Now
column2: briefly
column3: let me tell you how my prescription drug plan works.

column1: Al Gore : The governor talked about Medicare.
Al Gore : I propose a real prescription drug benefit under Medicare for all seniors
column2: all seniors
column3: and here's how it works.

column1: Al Gore : You pick your own doctor
column2: and nobody can take that away from you.

column1: Al Gore : The doctor chooses the prescription that you need and nobody can overrule your doctor.
Al Gore : You go to your own pharmacy and then Medicare pays half the price.
Al Gore : If you're poor
column2: they pay all of it.

column1: Al Gore : If you have extraordinarily high cost
column2: then they pay all over $4
column3: 000 out-of-pocket.

column1: Al Gore : And I'll bring new competition to bring the price down.
Al Gore : And if you pass the big drug companies' bill
column2: nothing will happen.

column1: Jim Lehrer : All right.
Jim Lehrer : Another health question

column2: where are you?

column2: there she is.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER : We spend billions of dollars every year on taxes
column2: or pay billions of dollars in taxes.

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER : Would you be open to the idea of a national health care plan for everybody?
AUDIENCE MEMBER : And if not
column2: why?

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER : If so
column2: is this something you would try to implement if you are elected into office and what would you do to implement this plan?

column1: Al Gore : I think that we should move step-by-step toward universal health coverage
column2: but I am not in favor of government doing it all.

column1: Al Gore : We've spent 65 years now on the development of a hybrid system
column2: partly private
column3: partly public
column4: and 85% of our people have health insurance
column5: 15% don't.

column1: Al Gore : That adds up to 44 million people.
Al Gore : That is a national outrage.
Al Gore : We have got to get health coverage for those who do not have it and we've got to improve the quality for those who do with a patient's bill of rights that's real and that works
column2: the Dingle-Norwood bill
column3: and we have got to fill in the gaps in coverage by finally bringing parity for the treatment of mental illness
column4: because that's been left out.

column1: Al Gore : We have got to deal with long-term care.
Al Gore : Now
column2: here are the steps that I would take
column3: first of all.

column1: Al Gore : I will make a commitment to bring health care coverage of high quality that is affordable to every single child in America within four years.
Al Gore : And then we'll fill other gaps by covering the parents of those children when the family is poor or up to two and a half times the poverty rate.
Al Gore : I want to give a tax credit for the purchase of individual health insurance plans.
Al Gore : I want to give small business employers a tax credit
column3: to encourage the providing of health insurance for the employees in small businesses.

column1: Al Gore : I want to give seniors who are
column2: well
column3: the near elderly
column4: I don't like that term because I am just about in that category
column5: but those 55 to 65 ought to be able to buy into Medicare for premiums that are reasonable and fair and significantly below what they have to get now.

column1: Al Gore : Now
column2: we have a big difference on this.

column1: Al Gore : And you need to know the record here.
Al Gore : Under Governor Bush
column2: Texas has sunk to be 50th out of 50 in health care -- in health insurance for their citizens.

column1: Al Gore : Last week he said that they were spending 3.7 billion dollars
column2: or 4.7 billion dollars on this.

Al Gore : Okay.
Jim Lehrer : Time is up.

column1: George W. Bush : I'm absolutely opposed to a national health care plan.
George W. Bush : I don't want the federal government making decisions for consumers or for providers.
George W. Bush : I remember what the administration tried to do in 1993.
George W. Bush : They tried to have a national health care plan.
George W. Bush : And fortunately
column2: it failed.

column1: George W. Bush : I trust people
column2: I don't trust the federal government.

George W. Bush : And that's what we ought to do for all people in America.

column3: sorry.

column2: you know

column4: therefore

column5: six
